Contributing to RAMEN

Source: .github/CONTRIBUTING.md

Hi there! This outlines how to propose a change to RAMEN. First of all, thanks for considering contributing to our package! Itâ€™s people like you that make it rewarding for us - the project maintainers - to work on RAMEN. ðŸ˜Š

For a detailed discussion on contributing to this and other tidyverse packages, please see the development contributing guide and our code review principles.

There are many ways you can contribute to this project (see the Open Source Guide). Here are some of them:

Engage with the package

Share the ideas

Think RAMEN is useful? Let others discover it, by telling them in person, via BlueSky or a blog post.

Using RAMEN for a paper you are writing? Consider citing it.

Ask a question

Using RAMEN and got stuck? Browse the [documentation][website] to see if you can find a solution. Still stuck? Post your question as an [issue on GitHub][new_issue]. While we cannot offer user support, weâ€™ll try to do our best to address it, as questions often lead to better documentation or the discovery of bugs.

Want to ask a question in private? Contact the package maintainer by [email][mailto:email].

Propose an idea ðŸ’¡

Have an idea for a new our_package feature? Take a look at the [documentation][website] and [issue list][issues] to see if it isnâ€™t included or suggested yet. If not, suggest your idea as an [issue on GitHub][new_issue]. While we canâ€™t promise to implement your idea, it helps to:

  • Explain in detail how it would work.
  • Keep the scope as narrow as possible.

See below if you want to contribute code for your idea as well.

Improve the documentation

Noticed a typo on the website? Think a function could use a better example? Good documentation makes all the difference, so your help to improve it is very welcome!

You can fix typos, spelling mistakes, or grammatical errors in the documentation directly using the GitHub web interface, as long as the changes are made in the source file. This generally means youâ€™ll need to edit roxygen2 comments in an .R, not a .Rd file. You can find the .R file that generates the .Rd by reading the comment in the first line.

Bigger changes

If you want to make a bigger change, itâ€™s a good idea to first file an issue and make sure someone from the team agrees that itâ€™s needed.

Report a bug

Using our_package and discovered a bug? Thatâ€™s annoying! Donâ€™t let others have the same experience and report it as well in an [issue on GitHub][new_issue] so we can fix it. If youâ€™ve found a bug, please file an issue that illustrates the bug with a minimal reprex (this will also help you write a unit test, if needed). See our guide on how to create a great issue for more advice. Please provide as well your operating system name and version (e.g.Â Mac OS 10.13.6), and any details about your local setup that might be helpful in troubleshooting.

Pull request process

We try to follow the GitHub flow for development.

  • Fork the package and clone onto your computer. If you havenâ€™t done this before, we recommend using usethis::create_from_github("ErickNavarroD/RAMEN", fork = TRUE).

  • Install all development dependencies with devtools::install_dev_deps(), and then make sure the package passes R CMD check by running devtools::check(). If R CMD check doesnâ€™t pass cleanly, itâ€™s a good idea to ask for help before continuing.

  • Create a Git branch for your pull request (PR). We recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description-of-change").

  • Make your changes, commit to git, and then create a PR by running usethis::pr_push(), and following the prompts in your browser. The title of your PR should briefly describe the change. The body of your PR should contain Fixes #issue-number.

  • For user-facing changes, add a bullet to the top of NEWS.md (i.e.Â just below the first header). Follow the style described in https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

Code style

  • New code should follow the tidyverse style guide. You can use the styler package to apply these styles, but please donâ€™t restyle code that has nothing to do with your PR.

  • We use roxygen2, with Markdown syntax, for documentation.

  • We use testthat for unit tests. Contributions with test cases included are easier to accept.

Code of Conduct

Please note that this package is released with a Contributor Code of Conduct. By contributing to this project, you agree to abide by its terms.
